awd_titl_txt: Establishing a Potential and Flux Landscape Theory for Stem Cell Fate Decision Making of Differentiation and Reprograming
awd_abstract_narration:
Decision making is essential for cell functions and realized through many underlying cellular processes, such as signaling, gene regulation, the development and differentiation in viruses, bacteria, yeast, metazoans, and mammals. Understanding the cell decision making for differentiation and reprograming, the biological process from a multi-potent stem or progenitor state to a mature cell and back, is crucial not only for uncovering the underlying mechanisms but also for the practice of tissue regeneration. Despite significant efforts and progress made in this field, there are still major challenges in the stem cell fate decision making: (1) how to define the cell states and cell fates and how to uncover the physical mechanism and dynamics of decision making; (2) how to quantify the differentiation and reprograming paths for the fate decision process; (3) how to identify key factors determining the cell fates; (4) what are the effects of epigenetics, micro RNAs and cell-cell communications on differentiation and reprograming; and (5) how is the study related to the reprograming and practice of tissue regeneration. Addressing these issues is the goal of this project and specifically the quantification of the stem cell fate decision making process, which is still difficult so far due in part to the lack of a quantitative physical theory as the foundation.

This project will meet these challenges through developing a physical landscape and flux theory for stem cell decision making. There are three aims. In Aim 1 the PI will develop the landscape and flux theory of stem cell differentiation and reprograming, and quantify cell states, dynamical rates, kinetic paths, and key regulations of the stem cell decision making process. In Aim 2, the PI will apply the theory to a core gene network of the stem cell differentiation in embryo development. He will further explore the mechanism of differentiation and reprograming. He will explore the effects of epigenetics through slow regulatory binding on differentiation and reprograming by modeling and experiments. In Aim 3, the PI will apply this theory to a realistic network for stem cell differentiation and reprograming involved in embryo development. He will quantify the underlying landscape topography, dynamical rates and paths, taking into consideration epigenetics, micro RNAs and cell-cell communications. He will also predict key genes and regulations for the stem cell fates and decision making process essential for reprogramming, which can be verified from experiments. This has potential applications on reprograming and tissue engineering.

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Systems and Synthetic Biology Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

por.por_cntn:
Decision making is essential for cell functions and realized through many underlying cellular processes, such as signaling, gene regulation, the development and differentiation in viruses, bacteria, yeast, metazoans, and mammals.  Understanding the cell decision making for differentiation and reprograming, the biological process from a multi-potent stem or progenitor state to a mature cell and back is crucial not only for uncovering the underlying mechanisms but also for the practice of tissue regeneration. Despite significant efforts and progresses made in this field, there are still major challenges in the stem cell fate decision making:  How to define the cell states and cell fates and how to uncover the physical mechanism and dynamics of decision making; How to quantify the differentiation and reprograming paths for the fate decision process; How to identify the key factors determining the cell fates. Addressing these issues is challenging and requires explicit quantifications of stem cell fate decision making process with a quantitative physical theory as the foundation.

Our project has met these challenges through developing a physical landscape and flux theory for stem cell decision making. We proposed the concept that stem cell fate decision can be quantified explicitly through the underlying landscape. Cell fates can be quantified as basins of attractions on the landscape. The cell fate decision making process can be viewed as kinetic transitions from one basin of attraction to another quantified by the dynamical rates and paths in between.  The key genes and regulations of stem cell decision making and reprograming process can be identified through the quantification of the landscape topography.

More concretly, we developed a landscape and flux theory of stem cell differentiation and reprograming.  We applied our theory to a core gene network of the stem cell differentiation in embryo development.  We explored the mechanism of differentiation and reprograming. We quantified the underlying landscape topography, dynamical rates and paths. We predicted key genes and regulations for the stem cell fates and decision making process essential for reprogramming, which can be verified from experiments. Above all, we provide a physical foundation and quantitative understanding of cell differerentiation and reprogramming at the cellular and gene regulatory network level. This has potential applications on reprograming and tissue engineering at the gene and network level.

Furthermore, we have also explored the underlying mechanism of the differentiation and reprogramming through the dynamics of DNA at the chromosome level. This provides the molecular and structural understanding of how cell differentiation and reprogramming have occured. This may help to design candidates at the molecular level to combat the differentiation related issues. 

We have explored the underlying physical and structual mechanism of differentiation and reprogramming from nonequilibrium landscape and flux perspective. This helps the fundamental understanding on this classical challenging issue in biology, and has significant impacts on the molecular and cellular biology as well as biophysics community.

The method development here can help network based medicine for drug discovery.  Understanding better the inter-relationship among differentiation/development, cancer and metabolism can help to design better strategy for treatment, leading to impacts in biology. 

The method developed can also be used to study economic and finanical market dynamics. The method and results can help to train the graduate students and post doctor fellows not only for the scientific career development but also for the industrial opportunities.

Course materials for teaching have been developed for biological physics from nonequilibrium physics perspectives in terms of landscape and flux theory, mechanisms of differentiation and development, as well as cell fate decision making. This helps to train the undergraduate students, graduate students and post doctoral researchers for the quantitative and physical studies not only on the differentiation and reprogramming but also on many other challenging and complex issues in biology such as cancer, ageing, evolution and ecology.
